comment: He expects you to teach yourself the material. He posts his YouTube videos online. There's a weekly breakout session with one problem that he gives feedback on. The whole class is graded on three exams plus the final, but the tests aren't bad if you watch the videos. Just stay on top of the material and you'll be fine.

If you take him, take his class in person. His online course is lackluster to say the least. The entire course is youtube videos, some breakouts, and tests. The tests themselves are not very hard but I would recommend finding a different way to teach yourself.
Teaches through YouTube videos. The tests are not terribly hard, all consisting of multiple choice. If you prepare and get an idea for the content you'll do fine. I recommend.
The course was relativity. So cool. Take and don't give up. Go talk to him if exam 1 is not good. It will make a difference. He knows his stuff.

Professor Garofalo is extremely knowledgeable about physics and focuses heavily on the theoretical side of things, which can make it a little bit difficult to follow him sometimes. However, he is very quick to respond to questions and makes himself accessible to you. Breakout participation is EXTREMELY important and leads to a lot of extra credit.

I though he did a good job of explaining the conceptual side of Phys 2212. For a class that's entirely online, I expected there to be more resources available to use when studying for exams. He only gives the answers for practice problems (instead of solutions) so if you don't have a good understanding of the content you're gonna struggle studying.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Garofalo made physics so much more easier and understandable. His classes mostly consisted of practicing problems. The exams are just very similar to the problems we do in class. His breakout sessions are also very helpful. Definitely recommend him for physics!!

Dr. Garofalo is a great professor and a great guy, when you get socialize with him. His classes were all lecture and example-based. He had three 4-question exams, and allowed you to retake your lowest. If you take him, GO TO ALL BREAKOUT SESSIONS! you get 15 points added to your final grade if you go to all! overall, very knowledgeable professor.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Graded by few things

comment: Awesome guy who is very willing to help with any and all questions. He is kinda hard to follow sometimes, but again just ask and he will help. My main issue with his course was that we only had 3 exams given there was one make up exam. It was hard to change your grade if you bombed an exam or didn't fully understand a topic.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Great teacher but course can be difficult for some

Enjoyed the class. I learned so much from his lectures and videos. He focuses on doing practice problems in class, but they are so helpful bc slightly modified versions of them are on the tests. 
TIPS: Watch his videos on YouTube, attend the breakout sessions for extra credit, and do the practice problems he posts on D2L.

Best Professor I have ever had. Took Physics 2 Lecture over the summer while working a full time job. He had ample extra credit and was a VERY generous grader. Even if you could not understand/solve the problem, showing him you could set it up would get you like 80% of the credit.

All I have to say is even though there is no homework, make your homework doing every in-class problem multiple times each. The tests are different variations of what is done in class or breakout but only 4 questions. He is a VERY lenient grader and okay at explaining things in class. His youtube channel is good if you get confused. GO TO BREAKOUT.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Don't take him. He only grades on 4 tests with only 4 questions each. The questions are mainly based on theory with no numbers, and it makes it harder to find examples outside of class. Professor is also really bad at answering questions and giving feedback. Basically got taught by my tutor the whole semester to make it out with a low B.

Class itself was easy. The professor tho is soooo bad at teaching. He doesn't explain the basics of it at all. I loved physics and was good at it but I really struggled to understand anything he said. The only good thing is the 15 extra points you get to your overall grade for going to the breakouts. The test are not hard. Its just his teaching.
Great Professor. Really lenient in grading. Awesome person in general.

No homework, finds lots of ways to give partial credit. Doesnt care how you solve the problems as long as you understand the content. Breakout sessions give 15 points to your final grade so it can raise it a letter grade. If you miss a few he will still give you some points just not the full 15

Take his lab class. I received an A in all of his lab reports. Just show up to the class and you'll pass. I never even heard him talk, he just writes on the board what he expects you to do. If you do it, you'll receive a high grade.

The professor understands physics very deeply but does not know how to teach physics I. He grades work very strictly but still gives partial credit. The class has no homework and very few examples of the work that will be tested. The grades consist of only tests, which although short, were VERY challenging. He also does not give good feedback.

Garofalo is awesome. There's 0 homework and no textbook. 15 extra pts on final grade if you go to the breakout problems. Sometimes he can be hard to follow, but every type of question is on his YouTube channel. 3 tests and a final, with a retake after test 3 on whichever one you want.

He is very straightforward about what he wants from the students on the exams, there are online lectures which show how to solve each problem type, and on top of that he is very helpful when it comes to understanding specific problems. The exams make up 100% of your grade, though you get a retake and are given problems exactly like the exam prior.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Clear grading criteria--Graded by few things

comment: This professor had no powerpoints, textbooks, or lectures with notes. Just practice problems daily. When I asked him for help he was dismissive, he would say my work is wrong but wouldnt teach or help me in any way. I went to him for help because I knew my work was incorrect and needed to be taught. He did help other students with similar issues.

PHYS 2211: No graded homework, only tests and breakout. Study what he does exactly during those and you will excel in the tests. Explains problems well in class. Helps you to get the right answer in breakout without giving you the answer. If you attend all breakout sessions you get 15 extra points on your final grade.

One of the best Physics professors. Almost every lecture is walking through practice problems, and the tests are in the exact same format. Class attendance isn't required but breakouts might as well be for extra points. Gives plenty of partial credit on exams as long as units/concepts are right. If you understand, you will do well, if not, just ask

He teaches the way i want to be taught: give me a study guide with questions like on the test, and do examples of similar questions in class to learn and apply concepts. 
Test 1 is "hard", test2&3 is straightforward. Test 4 is cumulative, and he gives 1 retake for test 1-3.
Show up to class & breakouts and do the study guide, you'll be fine. YMMV

Show up to class, do all the practice problems, review in class problems and you will be fine for the tests. He is a very nice and caring guy, sometimes he grades a bit too harshly, he really wants you to be able to understand conceptual physics though. I would take him again in a heartbeat, I feel like the information truly stuck.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: Go to breakout, he bumps your grade 15points if you go to every one. Tests are easy if you understand the concepts and example problems in class. For exp. there were 2 questions on a test that were the same exact question in our notes on a 5 question test. He doesnt expect students to know anything beyond what is covered in class. Also no HW!!

comment: As said breakout is key. Don't miss them.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Lotof people judged him quickly. I bet they would want to change their review on here after getting final grade. comment: Hands down the worst professor I have ever taken. Gives us no homework, gives us practice problems but with no solutions, his notes are useless, he skips steps and doesnt explain anything. The class is based off variables so no numbers. If you want to learn physics, take someone else!
absolutely useless as a professor. Gives no homework. Uses stupid variables. Doesnt explain anything. Do not take at all costs!
straight garbage, didnt learn anything. very bad at explaining and course content was worse than a garbage can
Very good professor limited by online classes. I would take in person but not online.
He spends a bit too much on theory but overall solid choice. I took him over the summer and he bumped everyone one whole letter grade which is why I got an A. no complaints here.
Read the board when you come into lab. He often only requires you to do parts of the lab instead of all of it. Normal lab. Not a picky grader.
HE LOVES THHHHHEEEEOOOOORRRRYYYYYY
His class is quite difficult and he gives you trick questions. Avoid him at all costs. Other teachers give easier tests with better curves to help you out. I would take someone else.

He really makes physics understandable and cares if we learn or not. If you have any questions, just ask: he will thoroughly go through it. Great professor I would definitely take him again if I had to take physics again. I was in his Honors class. If you are looking for someone who doesn't look at you like you are dumb when you ask ques, take him.

comment: While he's a nice guy, his class is next to impossible. Very little curve if any. There are much better professors in which you can pass the class.

comment: The subject is hard but after failing first test I used breakout to work on problems with professor help. That is secret. Almost none else did this and never improved. I got A.

There are 3 test (4-5 questions) each and a cumulative final. You have the option to retake one test. His way of teaching is okay because he just does problems on the board. No textbook needed, tests questions come from his notes. There is 20% extra credit which helps a lot.

You only have 4 tests (only 5 questions on them), option to retake one of the first 3. Lectures were hard to understand sometimes. Take good notes, Powerpoints are vague with no explanations which makes studying hard. I would say do not take the class unless it is required for your major. This was for ASTR 1000 class, did not let me choose that.

comment: Good lecturer but I cant hold physics ideas in my head so expect the prof to get them in my head or do some miracle but prof david cant do that and this not pointed out in his syllabus.

He is a terrible professor for an introductory physics course. All class consists of is doing problems on the board. When you ask questions he gets offended. His explanation of a problem consists of going back and showing you what he just did. He has trouble explaining the concepts.

comment: I found Dr. Garofalo to make no sense at all in lecture. I went to his office hours and asked questions during breakout, and was still completely lost all semester. He gives word problems which you have to derive a formula from, no numbers in any problems. Decent guy, but do not recommend at all if you struggle in classes such as physics

comment: He's a great professor. He's very heavy on understanding the concepts rather than simply plugging in equations. Grading scale is more than fair (go to breakout sessions, they help A LOT). No numbers on his exam questions, no formula sheet (he puts the formulas you need on the whiteboard).

comment: Cool course but professor expects you to think too much.

comment: I love this man. He gives so much opportunity to pass. You can retake your lowest test at the end of the semester and a 85 in his class is an A. If you put in the work youll do great. Hes a really nice guy and cares about his students and will answer any questions you have
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: Ive taken all my physics classes with Garofalo and have enjoyed every one. Grading is on a 15 point scale so 85 is an A and so on. Grades come from 3 Exams, Final, and homework and breakouts are essentially free points. Theres also a retake exam. I was able to exempt the final and got an A. Focus on the concepts and study the lectures examples.

Professor Garofalo is the best physics professor you can get. He focuses on the theory instead of math. He gives several very clear examples for each type of problem for a subject, and they are almost exactly like the questions that will appear on the test. If you email him, he will also provide sample problems that will prepare you for the test.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--TEST HEAVY

comment: Dr. Garofalo is one of the smartest people I have ever met! With that being said, he's not great at small talk or generally being open/friendly, but if you go to the breakouts and talk to him you learn that he's a really nice guy! His grading scale is incredible, basically impossible to fail. I made a 28 on the first test and I think I'll get an A!

comment: Very clear to follow along during class and he'll answer whatever questions you have. Breakout sessions also helps out a lot. If I actually had looked at my notes more than 15 mins, I'd probably made a B. Grading scale is great. 55+ and you'll pass. Wish he taught Physics 2.. He has a retake exam too.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Took him for lab. He just kindof throws whatever grade on lab reports, but mostly A's. Doesn't care about sigfigs or rounding errors. He literally just wants you to put down enough information to prove you participated. He specifically wants students to avoid sticking to the lab instructions verbatim, and encourages you to do labs your own way.

I took him this summer and he is one of the best professors you could have for physics. He explains the content well and his tests are based from the lecture notes. Tests are 5 questions. His grading scale is 15 points so an 85 is an A and so forth. The recitation and homework are extra credit.

Took him for a summer Physics 2211 class. It was rushed and difficult because of that, but he is an excellent professor. Attend class, ask for extra problems, go to recitation. 4 tests based off in-class examples, only about 5 questions each test. BUT, he is super clear and helpful if you don't understand anything. Also there's a retake exam.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: I really enjoyed taking his class this summer. He is extremely reasonable with the difficulty of his exams and has a great grading scale that has extra credit built in. Go to class + breakout sessions, write down the examples and study those examples and you'll be prepared for the tests. An A is doable here. He's a great professor!
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: One of the best professors I've ever had. To the point and very clear. I got a 38 on the first test but was able to bring up my grade to an A.  The best way to study under him is to copy the examples and do the examples by yourself until you understand them. Test materialGo to breakout sessions as well. You will be rewarded for hard work!

comment: Take him. Won't find a better physics professor. Big ole facts.
Cool course based on big ideas of astronomy

He does not pre-lab lecture. No explanations at all. We literally just started whenever we felt like it and had to read the lab. We would get so far and then just ask him or the TA for help and they just do it for you. Make sure your data makes sense to them and you will get a good grade. Some days you're only in lab for 30 mins. Easy class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: If you have to take physics he is great, especially if it's not your major. He explains all the material so the class actually understands what is going on.  The breakout sessions are a huge help, so go to those. The tests are not too hard if you study but he is strict with the partial credit so double check your work

Top notch prof. Took him for both lecture and lab. He cares more about how the students understand the materials given by exploring each ideas. Exams are based on the lecture notes, so come to class and learn!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Take advantage of the recitations which is a good way to test your understanding.

Teaches so that you fully understand the concept. Gives extra credit online and recitation. Do all of extra credit and will improve your grade by a letter grade. Test are only a couple very broad conceptual questions but very similar to all of the examples gone over in class. Take notes on examples and will pass the class. Never uses textbook.

Great prof! I took him for PHYS 2211 and loved him so I took him again. 2212 is similar to his 2211 with a few key differences. 1) He eliminates quizzes, so an easy 10 points is gone 2) The tests are slightly harder, although this is not saying much 3) The class is a lot more open and encouraging when it comes to discussions I highly recommend him!
Recommend
Physics is hard but the prof gives you a good sense of what you need to understand and how you need to understand it.  Exams aren't out of left field.

Professor Garofalo is amazing. Works plenty of examples in class that are used as the basis for his tests. Attendance is not mandatory but I highly suggest going every time. Recitations are used as an opportunity to work a couple of assisted problems for bonus credit. Excellent grading policy. Lab or lecture, you can't go wrong.

He's all about you understanding the concept. No calculations on quiz and exams, to make an A all you need is 85, HW and recitation gives you a letter grade so technically you just need a 70-75 to make an A. he is a really cool professor highly recommended

Very good professor. Grading scale is a 15 point range (i.e 85 for an A) and has only three tests including the final. If you do bad on either of the first two tests you can make one up at the end of the semester with no penalty. Quizzes are 10% of your grade and doubled score wise for a maximum score of 100% (i.e. a 52 becomes a 100). Recommend!

If you need lots of instruction he may not be the professor you. He does not explain the lab. He just lets you go, which can be difficult at first, but once you figure the equipment out it gets easier. He is helpful.
Great teacher just make sure you take good notes and look those over before a test.  This is a concept class.

Must work hard to understand the concepts because the ideas are difficult and they are mathematical and the professor doesn't water them down.  But if you understand the concepts you will find the math and the exams easy.

If you understand the concepts, and the equations that go with them you will do fine. The exam questions are conceptual and rarely have numerical answers. If the problem seems to easy it probably is. Focus on concepts and how they work. Book is good for this. Great teacher, I enjoy his teaching style. Grades fair.
